titleInfo.title: Charles de Rabars to Auguste Doussan, 1832 Sep. 22

mods.abstract: Charles de Rabars, (Brun?), to Auguste Doussan in Baton Rouge, 'État de la Nlle. Orléans.' Charles de Rabars, a resident of the Bordeaux region of France, served in Napoleon's army with Antoine Doussan. De Rabars also maintained a lengthy correspondence with Auguste Doussan, a relationship initiated at Antoine Doussan's behest. Auguste Doussan was the younger brother of Antoine Doussan. He practiced medicine in Grasse, France, and married Louise Perrin, who was a relative of the Allain family of Louisiana.De Rabars discusses the sociopolitical situation in France and mentions the advance of cholera in the Bordeaux area as well as the measures being taken to avoid the epidemic. He reports that Auguste is now married to Louise Doussan, née Perrin. De Rabars discusses his family life. De Rabars mentions the drought in the Bordeaux area and asks if the vine slips he had sent Auguste's brother arrived.
mods.note: (Brun?), September 22, 1832, Charles de Rabars to Auguste Doussan in Baton Rouge, 'État de la Nlle. Orléans.' De Rabars deplores the sociopolitical situation in France and mentions the advance of cholera in the Bordeaux area as well as the measures being taken to avoid the epidemic. He says that Auguste is now married to Louise [née Perrin], and he hopes that things go well. De Rabars complains about the trouble that his son has caused him, but the younger De Rabars has been home for a while and has returned to his old self. De Rabars mentions the drought in the Bordeaux area. He wants to know if the vine slips he had sent Auguste's brother arrived, and he will want to know if they survive in the future. The writer says that if Dubroca [apparently in Louisiana] remembers him, then remember De Rabars to Dubroca and tell the latter about De Rabars' nephew Dunogué.
mods.accessCondition: Please submit an LSU Special Collections reference ticket at https://askus.lib.lsu.edu/special for any questions or comments about this digital object.

Physical rights are retained by the LSU Libraries. Copyright has expired and the item is therefore in the public domain. Permission to reproduce this image must be requested through the Special Collections Division, Louisiana State University Libraries.
mods.note: Doussan Family Papers, Mss. 4800, Louisiana and Lower Mississippi Valley Collections, LSU Libraries, Baton Rouge, Louisiana.
